title: Citi Pakistan & PMN: Breaking New Ground in Microfinance Research
summary: Citi has partnered with the Pakistan Microfinance Network (PMN) to launch a comprehensive social impact study of microfinance in Pakistan. This initiative is based on a US$60,000 grant by the Citi Foundation, as Citi Pakistan celebrates its 50th year in the country.
tag-1: Citi Pakistan & PMN: Breaking New Ground in Microfinance Research
tag-2: Citi has partnered with the Pakistan Microfinance Network (PMN) to launch a comprehensive social impact study of microfinance in Pakistan. This initiative is based on a US$60,000 grant by the Citi Foundation, as Citi Pakistan celebrates its 50th year in the country.
tag-3: As part of this partnership, research will be conducted to assess the various ways in which the microfinance sector has had an impact on Pakistan's communities at a social level, generate best practices and share lessons learned.
tag-4: "The Pakistan Microfinance Network is a long-standing partner for Citi on the microfinance front," said Citi Country Officer and Managing Director Arif Usmani. "This pioneering social impact study with PMN is particularly significant as it reiterates Citi's commitment to developing intellectual capacity in the microfinance space in Pakistan. As we celebrate 50 years in Pakistan this year, we also mark the completion of the three-year Citi Network Strengthening Programme (CNSP) (2007-2010), in conjunction with the Small Enterprise Education and Promotion Network (SEEP) and PMN, based on a US$650,000 grant by the Citi Foundation."
tag-5: "Citi and the Citi Foundation's support to PMN has been very valuable in enabling us to influence policy making in the microfinance industry in Pakistan," said Syed Mohsin Ahmed, CEO of PMN. "With this social impact study, we hope to be able to study the impact of microfinance and gain better understanding of what has worked and what has not. We congratulate Citi on 50 years of commitment to responsible finance in Pakistan."
tag-6: As Citi Pakistan completes 50 years in the country (1961-2011), it continues to focus on developing microfinance as a tool for financial inclusion in the community through a series of programs based on Citi Foundation funding. Along with this US$60,000 funding to PMN, it has also committed to US$20,000 to the Akhuwat Foundation for an interest-free microentrepreneurship program specifically for female entrepreneurs in Pakistan to help them set up their businesses. This year also marks the completion of Citi's microfinance flood rehabilitation program with the Pakistan Poverty Alleviation Fund for enabling vulnerable groups (particularly disabled groups, widows and the ultra poor impacted by the floods last year), to regain their livelihoods.
